newsitem.title: FRANCE: Publicis founder's daughter to sell stake.
newsitem.headline: Publicis founder's daughter to sell stake.

text.p: A Publicis spokeswoman confirmed on Monday that Michele Bleustein-Blanchet, youngest daughter of Publicis founder Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, plants to sell her stake in the French advertising group.
But she denied a newspaper report that there was a row between family members.
The sale would be carried out only under conditions where "the independence of the group and its family control would be maintained," the Publicis spokeswoman told Reuters.
The advertising group is due to make a statement on the matter later on Monday, she said.

Monday's edition of financial daily La Tribune said two of Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet's daughters were embroiled in a row over one of them trying to sell her stake. The Publicis founder died a year ago.
It said Elisabeth Badinter, the founder's second daughter and chairman of Somarel, is using a complex legal structure to prevent her sister from selling her various stakes.
Michele Bleustein-Blanchet's holdings include a one third stake in Somarel, the Publicis holding company which in turn owns 38.4 percent of Publicis's capital and 45 percent of its voting rights.
She also owns over seven percent of Publicis directly. Altogether her share of Publicis, direct and indirect, is estimated at 20 percent, worth nearly a billion francs, La Tribune said.
